node.title: How to use a coupledArrayGradient ?
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Users,
I am trying to implement an AuxKernel that calculates the directional derivative of an array variable.
For this purpose, I am using the coupledArrayGradient that I saw in one example in the MOOSE framework postprocessors.
However, there is no example where such a coupled gradient is actually used,
not just imported, in the code in the entire MOOSE,
therefore I have doubt about how to use it, specifically, how to access the individual components of the gradient.
Let's say I have:
_grad_variable(coupledArrayGradient("gradient_variable"))
I assume the first index should the quadrature point, so:
_grad_variable[_qp]
and the second index should be in round parenthesis to pick the gradient of a specific variable in the vector array, like:
_grad_variable[_qp](i)
Is this correct? Or i means the 3D component, like x,y,z, along which I am taking the gradient?
How do I access the individual components?
You can check my class here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/auxkernels/ArrayDirectionalDerivative.C
Right now I assign the expression _grad_variable[_qp](i) to a RealVectorValue
and extract the components with round parenthesis,
I would like to know what is the best strategy in your opinion and if what I am doing is correct.
Specifically, since I need the directional derivative, I would need the scalar product between _grad_variable[_qp](i)
and a std::vector<Real>. What is the best strategy for this.
Your suggestions are highly appreciated.
Hope this can be helpful for others as I could not find any discussion here
with keyword coupledArrayGradient.
Thank you very much in advance.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Hello
Here's an example of using it
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/c42b80999f9a1a7aaa09c96484fc8a760f992359/framework/src/postprocessors/ElementIntegralArrayVariablePostprocessor.C
so [_qp](_component) for _u. Lemme check for grad_u
Guillaume

So for grad_u it should be:
_grad_u[_qp](_gradient_component * <NUM_ARRAY_COMPONENTS> + _component)
If you do
RealVectorValue bb = _grad_u[_qp](1)
you'll get a vector filled with (_grad_u[_qp](1), 0 , 0)

So this vector is indexed over spatial dimension I think based on what I see in your code. A simple for-loop like you did sounds fine for this operation, though I think there is an issue with your cast to RealVectorValue of _grad_u[_qp](i).
And the for loop needs to skip indexes in the grad_vector to stay on the same component.

Hold that thought I ll double check this
EDIT: was not what I thought. Previous messages edited so the answer's right

@GiudGiud  thank you for your answers.
Tomorrow we will go through some systematic testing and check that the gradient is calculated as expected.
For the moment I can only tell that this code works and when I print _grad_u [_qp] (i)
I am always getting a 3D vector, but as you point out, the behaviour may not be what I expect
and I may need to use (_gradient_component * <NUM_ARRAY_COMPONENTS> + _component)
instead.
I will post again tomorrow once we do the testing
Nicolò

I am answering this as I figured out.
Referring to the variable _grad_variable(coupledArrayGradient("gradient_variable"))
If gradient_variable is an ArrayVariable with n component,
then _grad_variable is an array variable with 3n components.
The order of the components of _grad_variable is the following:

the first n components are the derivatives along x of the components of gradient_variable
the next n components are the derivatives along y of the components of gradient_variable
the next n components are the derivatives along z of the components of gradient_variable

For instance a directional derivatives of an ArrayVariable are calculated as shown here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/auxkernels/ArrayDirectionalDerivative.C
Nicolò

node.title: Components to vector variable
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am transfering a vector variable from a main app to a sub app. For that I have to split the variable into its components using VectorVariableComponentAux. My question: is there a way to somehow combine the components in the sub app to make a single vector variable?
Thanks!

Hello
I couldnt find one in the docs.
But it shouldnt be too hard to make really.
Look at the VectorFunctionAux for an example of a vectorAuxKernel,
and the SelfAux for an example of a kernel that just copies a variable.
Guillaume

node.title: Problem with 3D Mortar Contact
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm experimenting with contact simulations and wanted to try out frictional Mortar for my 3D Model. But when I tried to run the calculation it exited with a Segfault (Signal 11). So I decided to update MOOSE to see if that helps. Now the Segfault is gone but I get another error right at the beginning of the first time step:
/home/florian/miniconda3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/metaphysicl/dynamic_std_array_wrapper.h, line 125, compiled Apr  6 2022 at 18:07:01
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 2

This problem is only present with 3D Mortar. I tested frictional and frictionless contact both setup with and without Contact Action but to no success. 2D Mortar seems to work just fine.
What causes this error to appear?

Hello
It s likely the AD container size that is too small.
Could you please configure with a larger derivative container size then recompile?
./configure --with-derivative-size=200
cd modules/contact
make

Guillaume
That worked, thanks a lot.

node.title: Error running make on MUMPS when compiling petsc
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to update the Moose on my account on XSEDE Expanse cluster but have error running make on MUMPS when compiling petsc. I previously successfully install it on the cluster. The error information is
"dlr_stats.F:343:12:
343 |         use DMUMPS_STRUC_DEF
|            1
Fatal Error: Cannot open module file 'dmumps_struc_def.mod' for reading at (1): No such file or directory
compilation terminated."
But I do found "dmumps_struc_def.mod" file in the moose/petsc/arch-moose/externalpackages/MUMPS_5.3.5/src. Also, I just followed the instruction on the moose website for the installations and did not change anything.
Could you please help me take a look at this?
Thanks a lot.
Best,
Teng

Hello
Sorry for the delay.
Could you please try again now? The petsc module has been updated.
The installation instructions for clusters:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
Guillaume

I tried to re-compile the software. Now petsc works. But I have the following error when installing libmesh
" /petscsys.h:535:25: error: invalid conversion from 'MPI_Comm' {aka 'ompi_communicator_t*'} to 'TIMPI::communicator' {aka 'int'} [-fpermissive]"
Could you please help me check this? Thanks a lot.
P.S. I previously successfully installed moose by disabling mumps. But I covered my previous installation with the unsuccessful one now.

Weird. What mpi distribution are you using?
What are the outputs of
mpicc --version
echo $CC $CXX $FC

I used openmpi yesterday. I tried intel-mpi today, and it works. Most tests can be passed. I received 14 errors for the last tests. I guess they are more advanced functions and probably I will not use them in the near future. If they can be easily fixed, it will be great to hear your suggestions on this. If not, you can close this issue. I will post related questions later if I indeed use these functions.
Thanks a lot.
Below are the failed test:
"mesh/split_uniform_refine.square ...................................... [FINISHED,min_cpus=3] FAILED (TIMEOUT)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.ptscotch_weight_both ................... [FINISHED,min_cpus=4] FAILED (TIMEOUT)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.parmetis_weight_side ................... [FINISHED,min_cpus=4] FAILED (TIMEOUT)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.parmetis_weight_both ................... [FINISHED,min_cpus=4] FAILED (TIMEOUT)
meshgenerators/distributed_rectilinear/dmg_displaced_mesh.pbc/adaptivity_nemesis  [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.ptscotch ......................................... [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
mesh/mesh_only.mesh_only_checkpoint ............................................. [min_cpus=3] FAILED (ERRMSG)
postprocessors/num_elems.test_split ............................................. [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
postprocessors/num_nodes.test_split ............................................. [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.ptscotch_weight_elment ........................... [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
mesh/nemesis.nemesis_repartitioning_test ........................................ [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.ptscotch_weight_side ............................. [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.parmetis ......................................... [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)
partitioners/petsc_partitioner.parmetis_weight_element .......................... [min_cpus=4] FAILED (ERRMSG)"

It looks like the petsc partitioners are failing which is not a good sign.
If you could please paste the actual error messages we could see what that’s about.
to rerun only those tests you can do
‘./run_tests —failed-tests’
Officially we don’t support intel compilers btw. I m not sure why they are working for you.

I re-downloaded moose and compiled again with openmpi. Now it works and all the tests can pass. It is strange that I did not change anything this time. I realized I should use the job script to run the tests. Yesterday, I used interactive job, which is based on "srun". Anyway, you mentioned that intel-mpi may not be a good option (I actually used gcc + intel-mpi, which may be a wried combination). It is good that now the default installation works.
Thanks for your help.

node.title: Trouble building Libmesh on HPC system, VectorSetAction is used but never defined.
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE team, I am currently having some issues when trying to get MOOSE installed in my local directory of a HPC system. I am able to build PETSC fine, but when it comes to building libmesh I get a huge array of errors, which are shown in the image below.

My currently loaded modules in my HPC environment are cmake-3.19.4-gcc-5-a7pima, git-2.31.0-gcc-5.4.0, python/3.8, gcc/9, openmpi-3.1.3-gcc-7.2.0 , and in my mooseenvironment script I have these variables exported.
CC=mpicc
CXX=mpicxx
F90=mpif90
F77=mpif77
FC=mpif90
This may well be question to ask to people on the HPC side of things, but thought I would ask in case it is something you can help with, if there's any more information I can provide to help just let me know.

Hello
Do you have mpich or mvapich available on this machine? We work routinely with those.
The openmpi module is consistent with gcc 9 right? What does mpicc --version returns?
For future reference we prefer you copy paste text in triple quotes over screenshots.
Guillaume

Hi, I believe MPICH is available but only up to 3.2. running mpicc --version returned gcc 7.2.0, I can replace the current module I am running with one that supports gcc 9.2. There are also later gcc versions available, I am currently using the modules I am using just because they are what was recommended.
I have tried re-running with
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --with-mpi --with-cxx-std=2011

And I get slightly further in the build I believe, but get this error instead.
  CXX      src/numerics/libmesh_opt_la-distributed_vector.lo
In file included from ../src/numerics/distributed_vector.C:21:
./include/libmesh/distributed_vector.h: In member function 'virtual void libMesh::DistributedVector<T>::set(libMesh::numeric_index_type, T)':
./include/libmesh/distributed_vector.h:580:8: error: 'scoped_lock' is not a member of 'std'
  580 |   std::scoped_lock lock(this->_numeric_vector_mutex);
      |        ^~~~~~~~~~~
./include/libmesh/distributed_vector.h:580:8: note: 'std::scoped_lock' is only available from C++17 onwards
./include/libmesh/distributed_vector.h: In member function 'virtual void libMesh::DistributedVector<T>::add(libMesh::numeric_index_type, T)':
./include/libmesh/distributed_vector.h:600:8: error: 'scoped_lock' is not a member of 'std'
  600 |   std::scoped_lock lock(this->_numeric_vector_mutex);
      |        ^~~~~~~~~~~
./include/libmesh/distributed_vector.h:600:8: note: 'std::scoped_lock' is only available from C++17 onwards
make[1]: *** [src/numerics/libmesh_opt_la-distributed_vector.lo] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/ir-elli2/projects/moose/libmesh/build'


Would you recommend trying to build with the mpich module despite it being a bit outdated?

You need C++17 support so this flag isnt going to work.
A bit outdated is OK, as long as you meet these requirements
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/manual_installation_gcc.html
mpicc on a different gcc version than your gcc module is a no-go of course.

node.title: Test setup and teardown with Python TestHarness
node.bodyText:
From my inspection of the documentation about the Python TestHarness and the source itself, it doesn't appear there is an easy way to do any sort of test setup or teardown. In the particular case for the MOOSE app I have developed, I need to copy a file to a specific location before the test and then remove it after the test.
Any ideas how I might go about this?
I suspect writing my own Tester might be the answer, but then how to link that into the existing TestHarness framework?

You can create several tests which all depend on one another, each doing a special job:
[Tests]
  [./testA]
    type = RunCommand
    command = "cp ../foo.i ."
  [../]
  [./testB]
    type = RunApp
    input = foo.i
    prereq = testA
  [../]
  [./testC]
    type = RunCommand
    command = "cp foo.e ../"
    prereq = testB
  [../]
[]

There are a lot of examples available in moose/test/tests/test_harness which we use as controls/unittests.

While this would indeed work, I'm not a huge fan of "abusing" the system like this. You can certainly add a custom Tester to the system. If you have your own app, it's just a matter of dropping it into the right directory in your App and our system will automatically pick it up, register it, and let you use it. While setup and tear down is a normal operation, we don't have a lot of need for that in our integration test suite. Note that if you use Gtest for "component" level testing, you can create those methods like you'd expect.
What are you trying to do? Can you just soft link those files into the right locations so you don't have to setup and tear down? Maybe we can come up with other ways of solving your problem.

Specifically this directory:
<app_dir>/scripts/TestHarness/testers

Thank you for answering this, and apologies for not coming back to reply. I did go with @milljm 's first suggestion in the end, and it worked for me.
However, I do agree this is a bit of an 'abuse' of the system that should be moved to the more robust solution of writing a bespoke Tester as suggested by @permcody . My use case was a slightly abnormal one: the input file for an externally run program (called from an ExternalProblem class) also functioned as the output file for that external program. So, a simple symlink won't work because the input file will have changed by the end of the test run, making it unsuitable for future use. This is why I needed the proper clone copy.

node.title: Deformation results are abnormal
node.bodyText:

and this is my input file.
cchf2.txt

hello
We're going to need to see the mesh as well, I dont see anything wrong in the input file, but maybe the blocks or the surface definitions are wrong.
Guillaume

I have checked  the mesh many times. Thank you for your help！
cchf.zip

i think your material defintions are wrong?
For example the claddings are 1 4 7 but really it should be 1 3 5 ?
I would just not use the block IDs. Use the block names that way you will be sure to get it right

node.title: Lagrange multiplier constraint
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am currently using LinearNodalConstraint to apply   constraints.
There are two formulation types, penalty and kinematic. the kinematic implementation seem to produce the intended result, however, as the mesh gets finer, the convergence fails most of the time for a simple elastic test.
The way that these constraints are set up is by forming a constraint for each node pair+independent node.
so my question is:

Do you have any suggestion of why would the convergence become very slow/fails with the kinematic formulation
if I were to implement this constraint using LM, what are your suggestions for doing so in MOOSE. I did see NodalEqualValueConstraint and it seems to do this using LM. is there a way to extend this function for my purposes?

Thanks in advance!

any suggestions on applying Nodal LM constraints in 3D would be greatly appreciated, I can see it's been used extensively in the contact module. but it's more general approach than what I need it to be since my problem is more straightforward than that.
I'm currently messing with NodalEqualValueConstraint along with OneDEqualValueConstraintBC. But I am not entirely sure on the role of OneDEqualValueConstraintBC in the process and how to adapt it for my purposes.
thanks again!
@lindsayad

Can you explain more what

means? I take L to mean "left" and R to mean "right", but I don't know what "1" denotes

*      E_________H
   *      /|       /|
   *    F/_______G/ |     the x node pairs correspond to the {AB,HG} edge pairs
   *     | |     |  |     the y node pairs correspond to the {AD,FG} edge pairs
   *     |A|_____|__|D    the z node pairs correspond to the {AE,CG} edge pairs
   *     |/      | /
   *    B|_______|/C
   *
   * B->1, D->2, E->4

 would be one of the corner nodes in the mesh, and it would be defined using a FunctionDirichletBC.
so basically for the equation above,  would correspond to one of the nodes on the face, and  is the "paired" node to it.
The LHS of the equation can be treated as a secondary variable that can vary to satisfy the primary RHS.
@lindsayad let me know if I should go over more details of what I am trying to do.

What physics is this? I've never seen something like this before. NodalEqualValueConstraint relies on a global (scalar) variable for the Lagrange Multiplier, however, I would imagine that you want to apply your constraint for multiple node pairs, so you would want your LM variable to be a field, not a global scalar. However, I can't visualize geometrically where the Lagrange multiplier degrees of freedom should live.

I am trying to impose this type of constraint mentioned in section 4.5.1 to form homogenous RVE from micro to macro scale.
if there is a way to impose this constraint using direct elimination that would be much better solution, but I imagined that LM method might be easier.
so for example here, one of the equations used is the  which apply to faces of the cube. by prescribing this relation the micro fluctuations in displacement should be equal to zero at the boundaries
there exists also similar equations for the corner nodes and the cube edges
example corner: 
example edge:
@dschwen are you familiar with this kind of thing?

I would imagine that you want to apply your constraint for multiple node pairs, so you would want your LM variable to be a field

I guess I did a similar thing, where i created a global scalar for each constraint equation at each node (which is a lot of variables, but I am trying to resolve this ASAP) but I couldn't figure out what to do to adapt the OneDEqualValueConstraintBC for my use.
this is the input file

  
    
      moose/test/tests/mortar/1d/1d.i
    
    
        Lines 50 to 66
      in
      f18a0bf
    
  
  
    

        
          
             [./evc1] 
        

        
          
               type = OneDEqualValueConstraintBC 
        

        
          
               variable = u 
        

        
          
               boundary = '100' 
        

        
          
               lambda = lm 
        

        
          
               component = 0 
        

        
          
               vg = 1 
        

        
          
             [../] 
        

        
          
            
        

        
          
             [./evc2] 
        

        
          
               type = OneDEqualValueConstraintBC 
        

        
          
               variable = u 
        

        
          
               boundary = '101' 
        

        
          
               lambda = lm 
        

        
          
               component = 0 
        

        
          
               vg = -1 
        

        
          
             [../]

In multiple dimensions, that IntegratedBC is not going to do what you want (it seems). I think what you'll want to do to continue with your methodology of multiple SCALAR lagrange multipliers is to use something similar to NodalEqualValueConstraint (modified to do your uL = uR + u1 physics) as the object that defines the Lagrange multiplier constraint residual, and then use CoupledForceNodalKernel to apply the Lagrange Multiplier to the primal variable u. CoupledForceNodalKernel is a NodalKernel which can be either block or boundary restricted. You will want to boundary restrict, and the "boundary" (nodeset) will correspond to the nodes that you are trying to constrain
